title: 106_s3162
content: The "Secure Our Schools Act" is a matching grant program for school security authorized under the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968. The Attorney General can provide grants to improve security at schools by using metal detectors, locks, lighting, security assessments, training, coordination with law enforcement, and other measures deemed effective. The Attorney General may give preferential consideration to jurisdictions with demonstrated need for improved security and financial assistance when awarding grants. Grants under this program may cover up to 50% of program costs, with the option to use appropriated funds for the non-Federal share of matching requirements. The Attorney General may waive or alter the matching requirement for recipients with financial need. Grants will be distributed equitably across different regions and areas, with a maximum of 2% reserved for administrative costs. Grants will be distributed equitably across different regions and areas, with a maximum of 2% reserved for administrative costs. SEC. 2702. APPLICATIONS. To request a grant under this part, the chief executive of a State, local government, or Indian tribe must submit an application to the Attorney General with detailed explanations of fund usage and how activities will align with the grant's purpose. The application must also include an assurance of consultation with various individuals to ensure the funded improvements meet the grant's objectives. The Attorney General will establish guidelines within 90 days of the enactment of this part for grant applications to prevent school violence. The improvements funded must align with a comprehensive approach and be tailored to each school's needs. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress by November 30th detailing the grants funded, funds provided, and activities carried out under this part. Definitions for "school," "unit of local government," and "Indian tribe" are provided in this section. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2001-2003: $30,000,000 each year.
